title: Photon Engraver - Mounting plate for microswitch endstop

description.text:
Mounting plate for 13mm width microswitch for common DVD chassis type to use with Isolt's Photon Laser Engraver ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:902826 ) or any other CNC type assembly using these drives. Mounting holes are m2 with 47mm spacing.

Here are the .STL files for a few parts I modified while I was building the Photon which may be of use to someone :
The external width of my engraver was 130mm so I've increased the width of the door and cover strips to suit, and extended the lower vent downwards so the bottom coroplast slides up to it flat.
With the DVD chassis I used I found that the V mount put the laser too far forward. I've reduced the depth of this to move it back, and also included a flat plate for a block heatsink mounted laser.
I left out the additional 12V socket and power switch so printed blanking plates for the holes.
I've included a clip which attaches to the LHS sideplate for this laser driver :https://tinyurl.com/ycgch9ra

title: oppo F1s case RWBY Pyrrha logo

description.text:
heres a phone case for an oppo f1s with Pyrrhas logo from rwby
its made for dual colour printing and works with a single nozzle if you print the logo first then the case around it

Printer:

HE3D I3 Prusa i3 clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15

Notes:

in your slicer remove the main case file and keep the logo

print the logo with a 0.3mm bottom layer height, it should have 1 layer

dont remove it from the bed

open the file again an remove the logo pieces and print the main case

print the first layer a bit hot so the logo and case fuse together properly

print at 0.3mm bottom layer height and 0.1mm for the rest

no supports so it prints over the logo (don't cross perimeters might help here but i didn't have a problem without it)

honeycomb infill

4 top and bottom layers

4 perimiters

i got the phone case file

imported an svg for the logo

extruded the logo 0.3mm to match the bottom layer height

placed it where i want on the case

duplicated it so there are 2 logos in the same spot (it will make sense)

used one of the logos to cut into the main case, it removes it while doing it so thats why we have the 2nd logo

now export into your slicer and split so the parts are separate

123d design wasnt cooperating and the file didnt import into my slicer so i had to send it to meshmixer then export using that, not sure what the problem was but this worked

Tronxy X5 bracket
by Blackluster, published Jul 15, 2017

During my presentation about rapid prototyping, I made an evil looking character on the fly during my inkscape tutorial. People have been bothering me to upload it, so I tidied it up and here it is! Enjoy!

This is a basic 10x10 expandable map (snaps to other pieces identicle to it) in which special tiles can be placed on top (held in by the grooves, kinda like legoes).  Included are a rock panel, wood panel, flat panel, and wall panel examples.  Additional panels can easily be modeled by the user as detailed as they like.  This is intended to make games such as dungeons and dragons a little more exciting and visual.
obviously you don't "print" rocks and what not.  The wood and rock ones are modeled as such, and would have to be painted after the fact. but yeah, use your imagination :3

Open an image (jpg, png, ...) with Inkscape.
Select the image, then "Path -> Trace Bitmap" and play with settings to obtain the best path.
Once you have the paths, export it into svg and use it with some CAD program (FreeCAD, Solidworks, ...) to convert it into an stl file.

This is an eccentric nut (aka a decentration post) to adjust the pressure on your wheels for your 3D printer carriages or other moving parts.
Design is based on the item sold by robotdigg.
https://www.robotdigg.com/product/626/Openbuilds-decentration-post
If you do not care to wait for the shipment to be delivered to your doorstep, just print it!

You will need 3 eccentric nuts like this to build the nice delta designed by Hadyn Huntley - Kumu-3D printer design: http://www.kumu-3d.com. In fact, 6 of those eccentric nuts, if you also use the back plate on the carriage for extra rigidity on the Kumu design.

This is a mark III version of a collective lever (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1578566).

It looks, feels and works better than mark II version. Just like its predecessor, it is based on the same SS495A hall sensor. This time you wouldn't need to adjust anything though. Just print everything, press fit an SS495A sensor, a magnet, throttle handle resistor, and two 608 bearings to their corresponding mount places, assemble everything with some m3 and m8 bolts and nuts, add some glue where needed (I used some cyanoacrylate to secure SS495A and its wires, also glued the decorative cover with the back plate of the throttle handle), and plug it into your joystick controller (I still use UnoJoy).

This is intended to be printed in PLA. Use 0,1mm layer on the main frame part. If you have any questions, regarding the lever, Simchair, or UnoJoy setup, please feel free to contact me. Comments, suggestions, remixes and improvements are always welcome!)

You will need:

1 x 250x10x10mm aluminum square pipe
1 x 20x10 aluminum rectangular pipe for chair mounting (the mount for the IKEA GUNDE chair is included)
1 x SS495A hall sensor
1 x 10KOhm LINEAR potentiometer
(https://goo.gl/vbi1Zh)
1 x 6x6x4mm square magnet
4 x 3x40mm screws and nyloc nuts to connect the frame to its enclosure
1 x 3x40mm screw for lever connector axis strengthening
4 x 3x45mm screws for tensioner halves contraction
4 x m8x75 bolts, spring washers, and nuts
2 x 608 bearings (standard skateboard bearings)
cyanoacrylate

You can plug this lever into your favorite joystick controller. If you don't have one, no worries, the software for Arduino UNO is included. Note that you will need an original Arduino UNO or its exact clone with atmega16u2 onboard.

How to use UnoJoy software:

  1. Upload the "simchair.ino" sketch to your Arduino with an Arduino IDE.
  2. Install Atmel FLIP.
  3. Turn your Arduino into DFU mode.
  4. Your board should come up as an atmega16u2.
  5. Run "Turn into a joystick.bat"
  6. Replug your board and it will show up as a joystick.

Note that ALL analog inputs MUST be either connected to potentiometers or grounded.

If you need two throttle grips and the collective head switch panel, you can use this twin throttle, 200 degrees travel version: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2747131.

The video below should give you the general idea of how it is built, though it covers the twin-throttle version as it is more complex.

---- UPDATE 30.01.2018
Noticed that some STLs were missing, so uploaded them and oriented everything in the correct position to print. Also made minor adjustments to throttle wedge part for an easier fit.

title: Monoprice Maker Select V2.1 Hot Bed Cable Bracket

description.text:
This is a bracket to help keep the hot bed wires from bending and hitting the build plate. It also keeps the wires low and away from a rear mounted part cooler when the extruder is near the rear of the build plate. The bracket is designed to work with the RepRap Champion Y Carriage Plate Upgrade for the Monoprice Maker Select / Wanhao Duplicator i3.

To install:

Place the bracket between the Y-carriage plate and the hot bed with the clips pointing down, near the hot bed wires. Hook the clip on the outside of the Y-carriage plate and slowly lift the end until the other clip clicks into place inside the Y-carriage plate cutout. It's a tight fit so some trimming may be needed. Once the bracket is in place, lay the hot bed wires on top of it and use a small zip tie and the provide holes to secure them in place. Make sure the eyelet of the zip tie is on the upper side of the bracket to keep it from hitting the frame.

I’ve been experimenting for a while to find a good way to improve the console of my Tesla Model S to give me a place to put my phone to use and charge and to give me a cupholder for slightly larger cups without having to sacrifice my armrest. This is what I’ve come up with and others may want to use it as well. I have a 2015 build Model S with the wood yacht floor.

This was designed to hold the Apple lightning charge cable for an iPhone. It would need to be modified to hold a cable for any other kind of phone. It holds my iPhone 7 and my wife’s iPhone 6 Plus without a case. Presumably that means it will work with any iPhone that uses the lightning connector. You may need to shim the connector in place depending on how your print goes. I used toothpick points to shim mine. This does provide more support to my phone than my Apple Dock does, but it does not provide full support. Use it accordingly.

I have also chosen to put a USB charge strip in mine which plugs into the 12V outlet rather than using one of the USB slots. It charges more quickly and allows me to add cables for other phones during a road trip. The one I am using is this one: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OHE8AOI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 It fits comfortably inside the print base and includes adhesive so it doesn’t rattle around.

I designed it to match the premium interior by wrapping the top and part of the base with black Alcantara (ultra suede). This wrap also keeps it quiet. I have uploaded the pattern to cut the Alcantara if you chose to do the same. I used 3M Super 77 spray glue to hold it to my PLA print. It’s not perfect and I’m open to suggestions for a better adhesive.

I found a machined aluminum cupholder which is a close match to the frame around the touchscreen. I got it here: http://www.eddiemotorsports.com/product/interior-parts/drink-cup-holders/billet-drink-holders/drink-holder-billet-med/ The anodized aluminum finish is a perfect match. It’s a little pricey, but it really looks great and gives the console a little of the aluminum bling that it’s otherwise missing. I have included a file to print a similar cupholder if you chose not to get an aluminum one.

USE THIS AT YOUR OWN RISK. Safety and security is a big concern with this. I’m sure you don’t want a big gulp spilling all over your car when you make a hard turn. I can’t control how well you attach this to your console or what other conditions might exist in your particular car. I used 3M picture hanging strips to mount mine and they seem to be working well, but I don’t drink Big Gulps. I’ve included a photo showing my particular installation.

I hope you find this useful. I love my Tesla, but have always been a little frustrated that they didn’t give me a good place for my phone. Used in combination with the Tesla Drawer and Glove Compartment Organizer that I’ve also uploaded to Thingiverse, my OCD is at rest.

If it looks really small when you download it, you may need to scale from mm to inches: 25.4.

description.text: If you want to turn your Nerf Stryfe into a PPSH 41, here you go!

This is a pair of wrench racks that I made to organise my toolbox.

There are two rack designs - one 8-piece holder and one 9-piece holder. They were designed to sit side-by-side, yet take up as little footprint size as possible - hence one of the racks is "reversed". The grooves holding the wrenches in the reversed rack have also been flipped, so that the wrenches all face the same direction when placed together (as shown in the picture).

The grooves that hold the wrenches are all different depths and widths because I made them specifically to fit the wrenches that I own, but they should be fine to fit most wrenches of similar size no problem.

title: Asrock C2750d4i (or C2550d4i) CPU Cooler Fan Shroud

description.text:
DISCLAIMER up front - I am offering the following purely with the view of information sharing and take no responsibility for any harm that may occur to people systems as a result.

The Asrock C2750D4i and C2550D4i motherboards are fairly well documented to have heat issues (which have resulted system failures) - for example see here: https://forums.freenas.org/index.php?threads/asrock-rack-c2750d4i-cpu-temperature-issue.41528/
This situation is certainly not helped by the passive-only cooling that ships with the motherboards. I have long monitored my C2750D4I CPU temps and worried about how hot it gets. I decided to design and print a fan mount that fits over the default CPU heatsink and allows a 90mm cooling fan to be mounted.

The design of the part was driven by the size and shape of my case (Silverstone DS380) - which is why the fan is offset and the overall profile of the mount is quite low. I have designed cutouts to insert M4 nuts (to take the M4 bolts that lock the mount onto the heatsink). To fit the nuts into place, simple screw the nuts onto a very end of a threaded bolt, heat with a lighter or candle (while holding the other end with pliers) and gently push the nut onto the part cutout. This forms a very nice snug fit. Then you just need to fit a 90mm fan to one end and bolt the other end onto the heatsink.

I've been really impressed with the results. Prior to fitting the adaptor, my CPU temps were 40oC at idle and 60oC under load (generated by transcoding a x265 HVEC file in emby). After fitting the fan these temps droped to 28oC and 41oC respectively (using exactly the same benchmarks).

description.text:
I've upgraded the Anet A8 LCD display to the display from the Anet A6.
(if you want one, search on aliexpress for Anet A6 display)

I replaced the original knob with this one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2449940

This upgrade improves a lot on the original display, the 5 button display is quite bad to operate.

This frame was designed to be a press fit onto https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2267628.

With this frame the LCD is more protected and also I think it looks nicer.
There is a 0.5mm inside gap to accommodate a 0.4mm thick clear plastic sheet (aprox. 78mm x 51mm) that will protect the LCD.
The sheet should be cut to be a press fit.
The edges must be rounded to fit.
I got the 0.4mm clear plastic sheet from a piece of package from a toy, I bet you can easily find it on a similar package.

The trick is: the stable phase holds position with one and the next after the next pin, but while moving the middle pin wanders out whilst being hold in touch with the curve by the next pin until the next after the next pin starts touching the opposite wall again.

For this to work, the outer curve of the inner curve body needs too be moved 0.1mm outwards to free the pin on one side to enable pin rotation.

With help of Google translated:

This is a cam gear with "Acceleration optimally inclined sinoide from Bestehorn" for experimental use. The generation of the roller and the pin bar is mainly parametrized. But there is no plausibility check for the parameters.

title: MakerGear M2 Flexion E3D-V6 Conversion System

description.text:
This is a system of parts to convert the MakerGear M2 to use the Flexion extruder combined with the E3D-V6 hot end. The system will allow printing of very soft flexible materials using the Flexion extruder on the M2.

The mounting bracket was machined out of aluminum and perforated with 6.35 mm holes to minimize weight and the maximize rigidity. I believe the bracket could be successfully printed out of a variety of hard materials with similar results.

Important highlights:

  • The bed fan rotates to permit easy removal/exchange and inspection of E3D hot ends.
  • The clamp part also holds and ducts the E3D fan eliminating E3D's fragile duct.
  • 25 and 30 mm long socket head screws are required to assemble the bed fan and motor/clamp.
  • All parts except the mounting bracket were printed from PETG at .20 mm.
  • All parts required drilling, tapping or sanding to some degree to allow for proper fits.
  • The clamp part also features magnets to hold a dial indicator for bed leveling (not shown) without the need for any disassembly.
  • The M2 extruder motor must be replaced with NEMA 17, 1.8°, stepper motor with a minimum torque rating of 0.2 N.m
  • the "E" stepper value in the firmware will need to be changed to approximately 100 and adjusted accordingly.
  • The MakerGear wire harness box was modified to attach to the the motor retainer.
  • The motor retainer holds the motor in position when the clamp is removed.

This modification to the M2 required substantial design time and expertise. I would not recommend it for novice printers. The primary motivation was the ability to print 60A TPU's and greatly enhance the capabilities of the M2. Enjoy!

author: joerodman

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PETG, but PLA should also be suitable.

description.text:
Automata 1

A small base for making miniature automata out of paper - a starting point for creativity - a quick print and an easy project.

https://youtu.be/snDho3lUhiQ

During this month of Makevember, I saw the excellent automata made by @wolfCatWorkshop out of scrap wood, paperclips and paper. I decided to try to make a simple base for making my own automata in a similar fashion.

Additional things you will need:

  • A 1.5cm wide strip of paper (the model has a 1.5cm slot to hold the paper)
  • Scissors to cut the paper
  • A paperclip
  • A pair of pliers to bend the paperclip

Instructions:

  • Cut the paper into a shape you'd like to animate
  • Bend the paperclip into a shape that allows the animation you'd like
  • Insert the bent paperclip into the model (long end, then short end)
  • Bend the 'crank' into the paperclip
  • Connect the paper to the crank, either directly or through paper linkages (In this one, I connected it directly with glue)
  • Turn the crank and enjoy your automata!

These are small and easy to print - it would be a fun group art activity!

title: Qi Phone Charging Dock for iPhone 8, iPhone X

description.text:
When I got iPhone 8+ I ordered this for a wireless charger:
Choetech T513 3 Coils Qi Wireless Charging Pad
http://a.co/54BESho
I have now made a charger dock and phone stand.
When the phone is in portrait it does not charge but it's at a great angle for viewing.
When in landscape mode it charges well.
The stand is designed to have the cable route out the rear and to cover the charging light, as it was too bright for the bedroom. I used this cable but pretty much any will do:
http://a.co/77kUGD4
It will work as a phone stand without the charger in place also.
There is a recess for the buttons so they don't protrude. Works best with a thin case, I use stock Apple cases.

author: jasonweichert

description.text:
This fidget spinner was designed off a image of a throwing star. Here is the web link.http://www.blowgun.com/shop/item.aspx?itemid=781. It is a toy so there is no sharp edges and 3 layers. The fidget spinner is quite long. It will be hard to spin if you don't have long fingers. The caps are a redesign of The Last Spinner Cap by Zigian -http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2285212. He made some awesome caps. I had to modify because if you paint, you need more tolerances.

The fidget spinner is 120mm long. The fidget bearing need is 22mm by 8mm.

3 Layer Ninja Star Fidget Spinner Originally printed as one solid part, I decided to make into 3 separate part. The reasoning was of cleaning up the supports was a pane. The second is you can easily paint the parts now. I was using Zigians fidget spinner caps because they worked great. But once I started to paint, the tolerances on the layers made them grind on the parts. Not a design flaw on his end but mine. So I took his desigh and modified it to have more tolerances to work on my part. The plugs I created were to short when you paint, so I made them longer. You can cut to fit as need.

Assembly Print -
2 - Top & Bottom Part
1 - Middle Part
8 - Plugs
2 - caps Note - if parts are not laying flat in the slicer, turn them so they are laying flat. You should not need supports. The plugs are the only ones I used a brim.
After printing the parts, fit the middle part on the fidget bearing. Make sure it is centered on the bearing. Next put the plugs into top & bottom parts. Try a dry fit to see if it snaps into the middle part. If it seems the layers are not totally coming together cut a little off the plugs. Once they snap together, take apart and put glue on plugs. Reassemble and put caps on and enjoy.

description.text:
There is already an FTC Relic Recovery filed made, but I found it somewhat incomplete. There was no relic, no Mat, and no side walls. I decided to add in some of the parts I don't have, such as the foam mat, or the Plexiglass walls, as well as an upgraded easier to print cryptobox. I also included a relic from another creator, Joshuasmith44.

To complete the entire field, you need to print 4 cryptoboxes, 4 mat with centers, one center connector, 4 walls, and 4 relics. In order to get the corner pieces for the walls, the glyphs, and balancing stones, see other field design by Eric Adams.

description.text:
Edit: Here is my version 2 of this - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2633184

No one had made the Emanator yet, so even with my limited 3D modeling experience set off to do it! This is the result of several tests, and I am very happy with the direction it is going. It is absolutely not perfect and id would love to see what kind of remixes people can do with it. My hope is this can get the ball rolling on a better design by people with a lot more talent than me!

I have included two tops, one with lettering, and one without. I am 99% sure the one without lettering needs a bit of "fixing" but I am including it just in case someone wants to mess with it!

Edit 11/7/2017 - I just uploaded a new variation, subject to change (I will post all my updates ) It is untested by me as of now, again will update once I print, but this has a more accurate inner part and a more durable pin setup. May need some repair prior to printing.

author: iTerminate

title: Essential PH1 Bumper Case (TPU/Flex Only)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a bumper case for the Essential PH1. This case has been designed slightly shorter than the actual phone, to provide tension after installation to keep the bumper on the phone. I've successfully printed on a Lulzbot Taz 5, using a .3mm nozzle, at 215C with a 100C build plate, using GizmoDorks Red TPU. I'd recommend printing a skirt to prevent the print from lifting off the build plate during printing. Models ending in _360 are 360 Camera Compatible.

Version 9 is a slim case with more exposed front glass, and more exposed back ceramic, as the lip that goes over the front/back is smaller. This is also the largest version of the bumper, if you're using a less elastic flexible TPU.

Version 10 Large is the same bumper thickness, except there is a little more lip over the front glass/back ceramic to keep the case on the phone a little better, and it's both shorter and narrower to provide even more tension when installed to keep it on the phone.

Version 10 Small is identical to Version 10 Large, except it's .1" shorter on the long edge to make it even tighter. This is as small as I'd want to make with the GizmoDorks TPU, which is supposedly similar to name brand TPU with an 85A hardness. Harder, less elastic TPU material will likely want to use Version 10 Large instead.

Version 12 is designed explicitly to combat the case coming off in your pocket, although this is likely overkill as the V9 never seemed to have significant issues with this. You will NEED supports enabled for this model, using Simplify3d allows you to tweak the size and location of supports to do the bare minimum. I believe I used a 3.3-3.5mm pillar resolution on the automatic supports, and removed any odd corner supports that were generated.

author: Baygull

description.text:
Check out my YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC82xXciVxsQKthONKeYbhnw for how to videos about 3d modeling, printing and home automation

Stand up desks are all the rage at my office these days, and a balance board one of my coworkers brought has been a big hit, too! Everyone (including me) takes turns balancing on it, and when I took a look at the bottom, I knew it was my next 3D printing project! I call it the "bottom bob" thingy...

Designed in Fusion 360, printed at 40% infill in PLA, it took nearly 7 hours to print when using Honeycomb infill. I've since then tuned my printing speed and infill (using Cubic) and got it down to 4 hours.

The board itself is a Laminated Pine Round (17.75" x 1") I found at Home Depot for $6. I used #6 x 3/4" wood screws to attach the bottom bob to the board.

Testing continues, while I figure out if this thing can withstand my weight (230 lbs), but so far, it seems to be working well and it's very sturdy (and heavy!) at 40% infill (honeycomb or cubic). At 20%, it stands up to my weight as well, but makes creaking noises (probably could be fixed by filling the thing with epoxy or silicone). I recommend printing at 40%, even though it takes so much longer.

I've also attached some photos of a board I made with black cherry stain/poly.

Check out my (mostly functional) 3D designs - (https://www.thingiverse.com/bkpsu/designs) ! If you like them and want to support my projects, use one of the links below when you're planning to buy anything from these sites (it won't cost you anything extra!). Thank you in advance!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/uXGg84
AliExpress: https://goo.gl/KRNurW
Amazon: https://goo.gl/nWhmjJ

Printer:

Self-sourced Prusa i3 (MK 0)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

40% honeycomb or cubic

Build Procedure
  1. Print "bottom bob"
  2. Get 17.75" x 1" Pine Round from Home Depot (or cut your own out of MDF or other wood, preferably 3/4" or thicker). <- You can also change the diameter, the lower you go, the more bouncy bob will be!
  3. Acquire 3/4" long #6 wood screws from afore-mentioned store.
  4. Measure out the center point of the board, plop bob over it, and attach it with the wood screws.
  5. Flip board over and balance!

print_settings.Notes:: I was able to print a plate full of these in PETG without brims on a PEI print bed - but don't hesitate to use a brim if needed.

description.text:
This clip snaps snugly around a standard sewing bobbin, preventing the thread from unraveling.

This is a great accessory to the Modular Sewing Spool Holder (shameless plug) - clipped bobbins fit on top of the spools.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Works great with the flexibility of PETG - have not tried it in other materials.

I designed this for FDM printers with 0.4mm nozzles. The thinnest parts (at 0.8mm) should slice to two shells thick. There is one negative angle overhang (45 degree chamfer) which should print fine without supports.

Your slicer shouldn't need to generate any infill for this print - it should be all shells. You may need to increase the number of shells to achieve this, depending on your default settings.

I was able to print a plate full of these in PETG without brims on a PEI print bed - but don't hesitate to use a brim if needed.

I took inspiration from a commercial bobbin clip with a similar design, which I measured with a caliper to get the basic dimensions.

I wanted a design that would stand up on end, not roll away, grip and remove easily, and have small protrusions at the opening to help guide the bobbin into the clip.

This was designed from scratch using DesignSpark Mechanical. I also spent waaaaaay too long getting the chamfers and rounds to work the way I wanted in DSM. :-)

title: Neo Geo Pocket 4-Way Gate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's not perfect yet, but if you need to play some proper 4-way Pac-Man or Crush Roller on Neo-Geo Pocket and don't have one of the official 4-way adapters, then this should work for now.

Basically, these two games came with little rubber gates that allowed 4-way play for the 8-way stick on the NGP and NGPC. It simply sits around the stick and prevents the diagonals from activating.

I printed this low resolution with PLA just as a test for sizing and such and it worked better than expected. However, I'd recommend Ninjaflex where possible. You can tell in the pictures that the one I printed is very rough...original gate on the left, printed one on the right.

Additionally, while PLA seems to work fine in terms of fit and functionality, if you NGP or NGPC has a glossy finish, then a PLA gate may not stay in place. As an example, it pretty much pops right out of my silver NGP, but stays nice and snug in my clear NGPC, which has a more matte finish.

My printer doesn't print Ninjaflex well at all, so I'd like feedback from anyone who can print this with something softer as it will likely function better and fit more units the way it's supposed to.

There's still a few tweaks I'd like to make to this but it seems to work well enough for now. Feedback welcome.

description.text:
Make your custom Snapchat Snapcode with this OpenSCAD Script. They work even at there small size.
I originally designed it to run in the Customizer, but the Snapcode png needed to be in a higher resolution than it would allow. It still works it just needs to be run locally.

Step 1 - Download

Download all this things files. Be sure to keep them all in the same folder.

Go to https://scan.snapchat.com/ login and download you Snapcode.

Then put your Snapcode in the folder with the other files.

Step 3 - OpenSCAD

Open the script in OpenSCAD which is available for free. Change the first variable to match your Snapcodes filename.

Step 4 - Render

Click F5 to Preview and click F6 to Render.

This is a complex shape so it will take a long time, please be patient
When it's done you can export your stl.

Step 5 - Print!

Print your Snapcode in yellow filament and then the Snapback in black.

Note: If you changed the 'Size' variable you will need to generate the right size Snapback by changing the 'part' variable to "SnapbackFast". I would recommend leaving all the other variables alone other than the filename at first and just using the provided snapback.stl you downloaded with the script.

print_settings.Notes:: Try not to use a brim with the pegs if possible. Cleaning the brim off of the snap-in parts of the pegs can be tricky.

description.text:
Intro

This is a modular sewing spool holder system that uses tileable snap-together bases and snap-in pegs.

The snap-in peg design provides some neat advantages:

  • Stronger pegs (the printed peg can be oriented along the X-Y axis)
  • Choice of peg length
  • Ability to replace broken pegs

The bases also snap together and can be tiled - the 4x4 and 5x5 grids have the same outside dimensions, so you can mix and match in a grid (see pics). I am working on additional bases for larger spools but they are not yet perfected.

Printing this Thing - TL;DR

Optionally print a small peg and base for calibration, choose and print the appropriate base for your sewing spool size, then choose your peg length and print the corresponding number of pegs.

Printing this Thing - Details

Calibration (Optional)

  • Print the shorter peg and the snap-in calibration base to make sure your printer is dialed in. The peg should snap into the base with a solid click, and be difficult (but not impossible) to remove.

Choose and print the right base

  • The 5x5 grid supports spools up to 19mm in diameter and requires 25 pegs.
  • The 4x4 grid supports spools from 19 to 27mm in diameter and requires 16 pegs.

Choose the right peg length and print the right number of pegs

  • The 66.5mm pegs should be just long enough to hold a standard height spool and its bobbin. However, if you put this in a drawer, you'll find that every time you close the drawer with any force, your bobbins go flying off the top of the pegs.

  • The 81.5mm pegs are designed with some extra length to hold bobbins in place when inside a sliding drawer.

Misc notes

The pegs are wider at the base to better fit a spool, and taper slightly towards the top until the last few cm, where the diameter is small enough to hold a bobbin.

The tallest peg height was selected to just fit inside smaller IKEA LINNMON drawers (this is the type of drawer shown in the pictures).

DesignSpark mechanical source files are included if you want to make shorter pegs. Don't try to scale the pegs with your slicer as it will mess up the proportions of the snap-in part of the peg.

(Shameless plug alert) A great accessory for this Thing is the Improved Sewing Bobbin Clip - clipped bobbins fit on top of the spools. You can see some of these in the pics.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

0.2mm is enough resolution for the pegs to function properly.

I found 30% infill was plenty for the base and pegs.

I'd recommend printing the pegs with at least 3 shells, which shouldn't leave you with much infill.

Try not to use a brim with the pegs if possible. Cleaning the brim off of the snap-in parts of the pegs can be tricky.

Push the pegs firmly into the base. They should give a good snap and be completely solid (no wiggling).

If using more than one base, you can click the bases together by laying one male/female side on top of the matching female/male side and pushing down gently.

I really liked the basic concept of the Spool holder for sewing thread - especially the multiple spool sizes in the same footprint - but it had a few shortcomings that I wanted to fix:

  • The pegs were too short for my use (wanted longer pegs to hold sewing bobbins on top)
  • The pegs were oriented along the Z axis, making them prone to breakage and challenging to print cleanly
  • The bases had alignment pegs but didn't actually snap together

Using the source spool holder's STL file as a dimensional template, I built a new design from scratch in DesignSpark Mechanical.

I fixed the peg length and strength problems by designing a snap-in peg system. It took a few iterations to get the snap-in peg tolerances just right, but printing the pegs separately fixed the strength problems (since I could lay the pegs flat on the plate) and the length problems (since I could print any peg length I wanted).

To solve the snap-together base problem, I took inspiration from interlocking track pieces from wooden trains. It looks a little funny, but it's just tight enough to stay put, and has the advantage of snapping together in any orientation.

title: Reed Switch Holder (NO or NC operation)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: We needed a reed switch for a project, and I usually prefer to make these types of things instead of buying them. This project takes a typical 14mm x 2.2mm NO (normally open) reed switch and either one or two tiny neodymium magnets and keeps them all secure and aligned so they will function as a magnetic switch, either an a NO or NC (normally closed) configuration. I got all the parts on ebay. The switches were US$4 for 10, and the magnets were about US$1 for 20 of each. I used old network wire and round machined pin headers (also from ebay) for the connectors. (I like using the round pin headers as simple connectors because they're quicker to trim than the square ones.) See instructions for details. The parts have think 0.2mm tabs around trouble spots - they can be easily clipped off after printing. I have a parametric SCAD file if you need different sizes -- just comment and let me know and I'll clean up the SCAD file and upload it. There's a video of how it works here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1MOFPqZxDA

Requires:
  • 14mm x 2.2mm reed switch
  • Neodymium Disc Magnet 6mm x 1.5mm (1/4" x 1/16")
  • Neodymium Disc Magnet 4mm x 1.5mm (1/6" x 1/16") - Optional for NC operation.
    • Instructions:
  • Print the parts and clip off the pads.
  • Bend the switch leads carefully so you don't break the glass seal. (e.g. use needle-nose pliers to support the wire you're bending)
  • For NC (normally closed) operation, put a 4mm x 1.5mm magnet behind the switch. For NO (normally open) operation, simply leave this magnet out. IMPORTANT: If you're using both magnets, then need to be installed in opposite directions. You can tell they're in opposite directions if the magnets stick together edge to edge.
  • Put the 6mm x 1.5mm magnet in the other side.
  • You can use a bit of glue to hold all the pieces in place if you need to.
  • Use #18 wire nails to install. You can usually just push these nails into wood by hand if you're using something hard like a flat file.
    • To install on a door, tape the two pieces together, magnet opening up. Close the door, put the pieces at the upper edge of the door, and mark where they should be installed.

nice design but some improvement easy to reach.
-the seat of the roller is flat and requires a washer, you could add a bezel , so the center of roller does not touch

-don't like the screwable bars, would prefer thin carbon fibers glued.
-add a clip for the ski stick, so we can store the folded bar while not in use.
-in the base you could also add a ring with holes for magnets, so we could set a preffered position where the axis go instead a free run.
magnet would attract but not lock, so bar would be still allowed to turn, but would get to preffered position.

author: Humpback_USCG

description.text:
This is a remake of Gatewood's pretty cool train horn. It is designed to work with 20mm OD conduit, which is cheaply available almost anywhere; unlike 1-inch piping. The spur is also now vertical, and a little thicker. Find his design here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:979623

PARTS
6 M3 bolts and nuts (14mm or longer)
Flexible hose (9-11mm ID, depending on stretchiness)
Something to use as a diaphragm (tougher than a balloon, but no tougher than an inner tube)
20mm OD conduit
A source of compressed air or CO2 (I use a modified paintball bottle).

PROBLEMS AND TROUBLESHOOTING:
Performance varies between diaphragms and pressures. If you can't make a fairly loud sound by blowing into it, chances are your diaphragm is too thick.
The pipe needs to be TOUCHING the diaphragm, but not pressed so hard up against it that it can't vibrate.

This design can be used by anyone who wants it. Have fun :) If you want the Fusion 360 files, I can provide :)

HOW TO PRINT:
If you print these parts with the biggest circle down, you can print the whole thing without any supports.

Make sure you have lots of perimeters. I'd suggest at least four.

The spur which connects to the vinyl tubing is meant to be vertical. This means you need to have your layer adhesion nailed down! If you're getting bad results with PLA, consider swapping to PETG. You could also try printing on an angle with lots of support.

Note that the 20mm conduit is meant to fit in REALLY tightly, so if you're overextruding slightly, it might be impossible! But you don't want to risk under-extruding the spur! If you can't get the conduit in, try scaling it up slightly.

Print the tip first, then you can check if you need to scale without wasting too much filament.

title: Large Stone Brazier / Bonfire - Tea Light - 28mm gaming

description.text:
I needed some cool light sources for my upcoming viking village encounters high in the mountains, and I had a ton of extra tea lights so I came up with this! Can also be used as signal bonfires, resized for smaller braziers, etc.

My tea lights were 20mm high / 40mm wide, but this should fit most standard tea lights. It's designed to print in two pieces for the main stone part, and the top piece snaps right into the bottom and shouldn't need glue. I have transparent red PLA, which I used to print the top flame. It works equally well without the top flame if you want to skip that, and just have the light from the tea light sticking out the top. The flame should snap right in also, but after paint I had to do a small bit of trimming to get it to fit - just trimmed the inside of the top hole with a utility knife a small bit. Enjoy!

author: jhaury

description.text:
This simplified wave was designed for a surfing retheme of a boardgame called Abandon Ship. I recommend scaling the underneath wave size to the height of the surfer, and scale width to the size of your playing board. My board was about 7 inches wide, which was just barely above the height the 3D printer would handle vertically, and the size of the wave front and back provided stability from tipping. Also, surfers can tumble off the back of the wave rather satisfyingly.

I'm am currently trying to get permission to post the files for the surfing Abandon Ship retheme. More photos, details, and hopefully file links available here:

Under the Boardwalk, an Abandon Ship game retheme on BoardGameGeek

I have also posted surfer meeples that fit the wave.

This wave may also be attached to the wall sideways as a ledge or moulding.

description.text: The back half of the PressurePen plastic shell. More information coming soon. see http://facebook.com/pressurepen/

A joint for attaching two rods at right angles. Designed for a retort stand, but could be used anywhere you need to join two rods.

The body part comes in different sizes to suit different diameter rods. To make a complete joint you will need:

  • Joint body to suit the vertical rod
  • Joint body to suit the horizontal rod
  • Two knobs
  • Four M3 x 6mm socket head machine screws

Print the parts with the flat side down. No support is needed. Screw the two bodies together. The screws should be a clearance fit through one body and self-tap into the other. Screw the knobs on loosely, slip over the rods, then tighten the knobs to secure.

There are body parts to suit metric rods from 6mm to 12mm, and imperial sizes 1/4in, 3/8in and 1/2in.

The example in the first picture is joining a 1/2in upright to a 3/8in horizontal. They were printed with AMZ3D orange PLA for the knobs and Prusa silver PLA for the bodies.

author: greenail

title: TEAL drone top cover with LEGO studs.

description.text:
I looked up the dimensions for LEGO bricks then modeled a plate full of studs to merge with the TEAL drone top cover.

It might need some reinforcing ribs on the underside of the new, cut out area beneath the plate. The increased room could also be used to add mountings for additional equipment inside the drone. Perhaps some PCB mounts for electronics to go with things snapped on top.

The bottom of the plate area could be made with hollow tubes like LEGO. The studs on top could also be made hollow to expand the attachment possibilities.

I wanted to keep the design light weight, which is why the addition is hollowed out. More weight = less flying time and less speed. Who wants that?

title: Proxxon Säge Motorhalter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is for the small Proxxon KS-230 desk circular saw.
It makes a holder for a more powerfull brushless DC motor that replaces the weak stock 80 watt AC motor.
Those DC-motors can be found in RC-models, mostly planes.
Some electronical regulators requiered. Buy one for providing high amperage power and the other for regulation of the shaft speed .
The idea came from a guy hwo presented his mod on youtube, but he wants to make money from it.
So I have constructed a fresh model.
Have fun.

The files:
-the dxf file contains the 2 dimensional drawing
-the Openscad file that imports the dfx-file for extrusion
The small holes are intended to be 5mm, the one in the center 12.5mm.
Update:
added to the first line $fn=100; to force OpenScad making the imported holes round

-the stl-file ready for printing (perfect holes)

  • if you have access to a CNC router, make that thing from metal, highly recommended

What's next:

  • If you have a motor that fits - fine.
    simply print out the stl.file.
  • If you are adapting the plate for other dimensions, take the dfx file and do what you want from it.
    Eventually I have made the stl from 123Designer loading the dfx file in and added the chamfers.
    If you are not using 123design or similar 3D CAD (for the chamfered holes):
    the chamfers can be made manually if you print out a solid from the extruded dxf file.
    OpenScad can export the extruded dfx file to stl.
    Take the same regular tools used for making (sunken) holes when working with wood ;-)
    Choose very low speed or turn the tool by hand.

As of writing the program files can be downloaded from here:

  • 123design installer for Windoze
    http://autodesk-123d-design.en.lo4d.com/download
  • If you have purchased 123design for OSX (at no charge) earlier you can download it from the Appstore again
  • QCad (OSX, Windoof, Linux)
    https://www.qcad.org/en/qcad-downloads-trial
    The free trial remains the full basic version without CAM-plugins after the trial period.
  • Openscad DL (OSX, Windoof, Linux)
    http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html

The manufacturers multlingual install manual (stock motor)
http://downloads.cdn.re-in.de/800000-824999/823004-an-02-de-TISCHKREISSAEGE_KS230_PROXXON.pdf
View of the stock motor with mountplate
https://www.fluidonline.de/item/images/1686/750x1000/1686-prox-27006-06-motor-ks230-1.jpg
Buildlog make the KS230 anything good for now
http://www.rc-network.de/forum/showthread.php/346226-Umbau-einer-Proxxon-KS230-auf-brauchbar
He added two new sunken holes at a swiveled line to the stock mountplate and he has turned down the 8mm motor shaft to 6mm on a lathe

author: makibox850

title: PLA FAN
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
PLA FAN

Normally I print with ABS and PET-G. I like these materials very much but they have their own problems.
They are not very cheap materials to waste.
Printing with ABS and PET-G will also take much more time and it is not recommended to cool it.
That’s the reason I do not have cooling fans on my printers for cooling the printed material.
But my BIG DIY 3D Printer is so huge, that printing big object, takes even more time.
Also it’s more expensive if a print fails.
For this reason I decided to print with PLA on my BIG DIY 3D Printer.
That’s the reason for this Fan.

I used four 30x30mm fans because I had those.
It is also adjustable for aiming the airflow.
The kapton tape is there for protection against the heat, but I already had the problem that is can lose during the print. So that something to take in account using it. If I would do this again, I probably will not use the tape again and just accept the temporary nature of the housing :-).

This fan is easy to install and take not so much room.

But after testing this fan I came to the conclusion that it has one drawback.
It can cool only from one direction which can make the print to fail.

Therefor if you have the space, I recommend PLA FAN 2 : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2630552

See also:
BIG DIY 3D Printer : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2603668

Easy exchange filament extruder : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601366

title: PLA FAN 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
PLA FAN 2
Because my PLA FAN can only cool from one side,
I made a second one. This one has a much bigger housing, so it will take more room.
This one is designed to spread the air 360 degrees around the nozzle in such a way it doesn’t hit the nozzle.
This design is made in two parts with the great advantage that the inside of the housing can be printed very smooth.
That will take the air resistance down and thus the airflow up. It will also extend the fans life and reduce noise.
I printed tis model in translucent PET-G so the light from the LED, which is mounted on the bottom of the X wagon, can come through.
There is already support material added on the main body, which has to be removed afterwards. See print screen for more info.
The main body and the lid are also glued together at the outer ends.
For the mounting of this FAN housing I needed other brackets.
The bracket at the timing belt side has also an extra option for mounting a “timing belt stabilizer”.
If the timing belts are long they are more likely to fibrate as a snare on a guitar. For this problem it helps to install this part.
The idea is that it slightly holds (or touches) the timing belt and thus takes the vibrations out.
It also uses three bearings 623ZZ (diameter 10mm x 4mm, bore is 3mm).
This one is recommend for spiral vase mode for sure :-)

See also :
PLA FAN : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2630547

BIG DIY 3D Printer : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2603668

Easy exchange filament extruder : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601366

description.text:
heres a phone case for an oppo f1 with the fl4t logo for subie fans
its made for dual colour printing and works with a single nozzle if you print the logo first then the case around it

Printer:

prusa i3 clone

No

Resolution:

0.15

15

Notes:

in your slicer remove the main case file and keep the logo

print the logo with a 0.3mm bottom layer height, it should have 1 layer

dont remove it from the bed

open the file again an remove the logo pieces and print the main case

print the first layer a bit hot so the logo and case fuse together properly

print at 0.3mm bottom layer height and 0.1mm for the rest

no supports so it prints over the logo (don't cross perimeters might help here but i didn't have a problem without it)

honeycomb infill

4 top and bottom layers

4 perimiters

i got the phone case file

imported an svg for the logo

extruded the logo 0.3mm to match the bottom layer height

placed it where i want on the case

duplicated it so there are 2 logos in the same spot (it will make sense)

used one of the logos to cut into the main case, it removes it while doing it so thats why we have the 2nd logo

now export into your slicer and split so the parts are separate

title: Roland Boutique Three-Tier Rack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a Three-Tier rack for Roland Boutique Synthesizers.

Please note this rack requires the DK-01 dock. If your Boutique synths do not have the DK-01 Dock they will not fit properly in this rack. Synths like the TR-09, TB-03 and TR-08 come with a DK-01 so those will all fit properly, but all other Synths will need the DK-01 dock from Roland in addition. You can contact your local music retailer to purchase the DK-01 Dock(s) if you need them. Any additional materials needed to build this rack are listed below under the BOM.

Also, please note that the middle synth slot in this rack you will not be able to use the MIDI DIN connections. For USB connectivity you will need to use a low profile or angled Micro USB cable. I can recommended the cable I'm using is from the USBFirewire web store, part # RR-ADMCB-72G

title: RamjetX Thrustmaster T300 T500 TX TSPC 70mm Hub Adaptor Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi Internet Sim Racers,

After doing a final test print of my Thrustmaster Txxx 70mm hub adaptor kit... I feel it's ready for public thrashing.

Ok, so whats in the pack I hear you ask... through some form of audio bug I have in your room... don't worry about it.. just let it happen... anyway I digress..

Whats in the pack:

1 x Thrustmaster Quick Release threaded Hub with a 70mm PCD pattern for common after market steering wheels.

1 x Matching real Quick Release adaptor for that type showing in the photos. Very common on ebay. They feel alright and not too much play in them.

Why did I make this pack? Well, it started off as an excuse to learn Fusion 360 (AMAZING CAD package btw)... Now that I made this, I have the base files I need to modify and build the matching button plates etc etc... it's kinda going to a whole eco system thing.

Don't worry, I'll release them here too...

What makes this one different? The integrated 6 Pin DIN connector in the middle is accurately modelled and is ready to push in a connector and expand the original port.

Surely someone will find this useful and I thought I'd share in my joy that has been learning to 3D Model.

Enjoy!

And don't drink and virtually drive!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

I print with 40mm per second... it takes nearly 8 hours. But the finish is stunning and the slower I went, the better layer adhesion and strength it had. Make Walls, Top and Bottom all 2mm thick. Your aiming to make the threaded section to be solid infill whilst the main plate body can be infill as normal. So check this in your layer view before exporting the gcode.

You really wanna build this strong as it's going to cop a pounding.

I made it with PLA. It's solid and more than enough to do the job.

Now, quick thing on flow. I printed with 110% on my Wanhao. This will vary for everyones printer. The tolerence in the centre is tight. It's supposed to be. You don't want wiggle in your wheel. Now if its too tight, you've probably gone heavy on your flow. Thats okay, just heat it up with a hair dryer and push it on and it'll be snug as a bug.

author: bricerive

description.text:
Hey guys, this project came about because my good set of hex bits snapped. I did not have any money to buy a new set so I decided to make one for cheap instead. A good hex driver set can go from $30 and above but with this, you could easily cut the price down to $1 for each driver.

I have not tested every single file so if there is anything wrong with any of them, please message me! I will be adding various more handles, so if you have any suggestions of a specific type of handle you'd like, message me! Thank you!

This design will fit:

  • Metric: 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 5.5, 6.0.
  • SAE / Inch / American: 1/8, 1/16, 3/16, 3/32, 5/32, 5/64, 7/32, 7/64, 9/64.

NOTE:

  • I have used left handed screw threads for this project.
  • The handle has a pilot hole so you could use any screw to hold the "Holder" parts against the handle. I used an M3x10 button screw for mine.
  • If you choose to have a thumb screw on the handle, you could have interchangeable keys!
  • Depending on your printer, you may need a nozzle smaller than 0.4mm to print the 6mm key and the 9/64 key.

Printing Tips:

  • You would need to flip the "Holder" files 180 degrees, and add supports that are only touching the build plate.
  • You will need to flip the "Ring" files 180 degrees. These files do not need any supports.
  • The handles should be printed up right with no supports as well.
  • The tolerance of my parts is + 0.3mm from true measurements. This yielded a perfect fit for my printer (Anet A8).

Interpreting the files:

  • The screwdriver is composed of four pieces: "Holder" (2 halves), "Ring", and handle.
  • Each file has the size of the key you would want to use for it.
  • The "Holder" is composed of two pieces and is labeled "L" or "R" to differentiate them.

Example: If you have a 1.5mm hex key you would need to print "Holder_1.5mmL", "Holder_1.5mmR", "Ring_1.5mm" and your handle of choice.

Print Settings (What I used and recommend):

  • I used a 0.4 mm nozzle.
  • Printed in PETG plastic (Any plastic could be used).
  • I used 40% infill for the handle with 3 layer walls.
  • I highly suggest 100% infill for the "Ring" files and at least 40% infill on the "Holder" files.

remixed_from.title: Customizable Linear Bushing / Bearing - LM8UU, LM8LUU, LM12UU, LM12LUU, LM16UU, ...  IGUS like

title: HyperCube X Bushing (mightynozzle Igus design)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This just takes Artur's X bushing code and uses mightynozzle's Igus-like bushing instead.

See sections below for instructions.

Printer:

HyperCube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

Designed to be printed with 0.48mm extrusion width and 4 perimeters.

I needed the Simplify3D setting Advanced, Internal Thin Wall Type, Allow Single Extrusion Fill to ensure walls are solid.

I'm not sure of the equivalent in Cura or Slic3r sorry.

Sizing

I have included several sizes in 0.25mm steps for 10mm shaft, 8mm shaft, and imperial shafts close to those values. However, I suggest you don't use the pre-made sizes, and instead size precisely for your rods.

Use the OpenSCAD source and vary the inner diameter of the bushing. Do small test prints 8mm tall until you get within 0.1mm of your rod size. Then use full-height prints to dial down to the exact 0.01mm size where the bushing grips the rod and won't fall with gravity anymore. Use that size as the ideal bushing for your specific rod/printer/filament combination.

When you get the size ideal, print at least two spare sets so you can make the printer work again when the first set wear out, because you might need your printer to be working well to make more precise parts so the printer can work well again. Save yourself the catch 22.

You need to have Tech2C's file Dual_bushing_holder.stl in the same directory as the OpenSCAD source.

Lubricant

I recommend lubricating with thick silicone oil like is used in RC car diffs and shock absorbers. You can get it on eBay. I am using "Team Affiliated 10000 Weight".

I have previously used dry PTFE lube like Super Lube, or Muc-Off Bio Dry Lube and these were okay but needed re-lubing every two weeks or so.

Anything which does plastic-to-metal should work. Don't use a petroleum-based lube like 3-in-One or Vaseline, plastic degrades with that sort of lubricant.

Butte Metz found out that if you soak PLA bushings in silicone spray for a couple of weeks, they become "self lubricating" like Igus bushings or Nylon. Even after using silicone oil on rods for a couple of months this seems to be true, no need for pre-soaking.

Material

PLA: Recommended. I have tried PLA and it works well.

PETG: I have heard others say PETG is also a good option which works well, I've never tried it myself. PETG does have a lower Coefficient of Friction vs Steel than PLA so theoretically that's correct.

Exotic/Expensive: Nylon 6, Nylon 6/6, polycarbonate, POM, and Igus Tribofilament would also all be good choices if you have them lying around.

ABS: ABS is not suitable. Don't use ABS for these.

Y Bushings

For Y bushings you can just use the original mightynozzle code directly. Make sure you print the Y bushings undersize, so they are 14.8-14.9mm on the external diameter and not 15.0mm like a metal LM8UU.

You want the bushing outer diameter slightly loose in the XY Joiner, then use teflon plumber's tape or kapton tape or blue painter's tape to make them fit snug but compress down on the tape, not compress down on the bushing.

If you make the printed Y bushings too big and compress the bushing as you tighten down the XY Joiner cap, then the bushings change shape and will bind on the metal shaft.

Artur and Adrian have done remixes where the bushing is actually integrated into the XY Joiner cap. If there's any interest in that, let me know and I'll design one up. I might do it for myself anyway.

author: hk3455

title: Kossel / 2040 Mount Adapter for Bondtech's Standard Mount.

description.text:
This simple adapter allows the Bondtech extruder to mounted onto 2040 extrusion using their standard mount. This allows enough clearance on 2040 for the carriages to ride in the front rail.

Standard mount is here - http://www.bondtech.se/en/products/freebies-stl-files/ For my motor I had to remove the locating tab with a knife.

I used m4 x20 button head screws to mount the standard mount to the adapter with washers and some nylock nuts. The same screws were also used to fit the top of the mount.

You'll see I'm using capricorn tube, this has a lower internal size but to stop it coming out I had to reverse the extruder and use the bowden adapter they sell separately.

description.text: sphere to be scaled. this thing including foots to be printed directly without support material.

Ahoy mateys! The Cap'n Crunch Bo'sun whistle, originally a prize toy in boxes of cereal, became the stuff of legend as a tool for phone freaks (phreakers) delving the depths of telecom networks in the 1960s. Because it emitted a tone of 2600Hz, the same tone used by AT&T's system to signal a line to open and prepare for connection, it could be used to manipulate the system and make free calls. The 2600Hz signaling protocol is no longer in place, but phreakers' use of the whistle remains a touchstone of ingenuity in the history of hacking. Re-live the excitement with this 3D printed replica!

Compare the sounds of the original and printed whistles here: https://youtu.be/2qwcc3cKmsA

The fabled phreaker John Draper, who popularized use of the Cap'n Crunch whistle for network exploration, shows how he used to open a phone line and dial a number in this video: https://vimeo.com/112783389

Printing tips:

  • Orient the whistle mouthpiece down
  • Include a skirt starting 0.00mm from the object with 4 layers and 25 outlines
  • Use 100% infill
  • Add external support only (Internal support will block air flow and the whistle won't work)
  • If you print in abs, smooth the whistle with acetone to get a great sound
  • Getting a perfect 2600Hz pitch is a challenge - scale your print to different sizes to
    tweak it up and down

Update: Andy Cohen, cohost of the 3D Printing Today podcast, kindly sent me a repaired version of the whistle mesh that resolves a number of problems with slicing. It is the best one to print.

comments.text: It can be a little tricky to print due to the thin walls and the inner areas. Assuming you have S3D... I suggest slowing it down, use no infill, make the extrusion width .3 (Manual) and 2 shells. Up the heat a bit too to ensure it's water tight.

The „Tea-Gallows“ is a nice little gadget working with an Atmel Atmega328 on an application board. Pushing the button increases the brewing time indicated from LEDs for one minute until a maximum of eight minutes. A long push starts the countdown. The alarm starts ten seconds before the end with short peeps until finally the tea bag will be pulled out through a weight falling down along a little pole made of stainless steel. The release process is caused by a tiny servo pulling back a bolt holding the weight in place. I decided to power it with 4,5V, supplied by three AAA-batteries. Therefore there’s no external crystal; besides the µC goes into power-down-mode when the µC is not active for 10 seconds, consuming only about 25µA.

Programming the µCs needs a ISP-programmer, because you have to set some fuses of the µC, which you can’t do with serial programming (I’m no expert, but I think that’s right). I recommend the following little application board:

http://shop.anvilex.de/index.php?route=product/product&path=115_222&product_id=2641

You can use a Arduino NanoProMini too, but regarding battery life you have to desolder a power LED and a voltage regulator. ISP-programming means a little bit more effort, because the Arduinos are in first line made for FTDI-programming.

Please be sure to use LEDs with integrated protective resistor, never connect a normal LED directly to a µC. Don't forget the protective resistor for the photomos relay too, it will be damaged without.

My printer is a Robo3D R1. All parts are printed with PLA. Only the two halfs of the little bolt are printed with a layer height of 0,2mm with low printing speed of 1800mm/min. All other parts are printed with a layer height of 0,3mm. Support is necessary for two items: bottom and panel. All stl-files show the parts in correct printing orientation.
Tap a M3 thread Drill out to 4mm Optionally add some device feet

Software

Designed with a free version of “Creo Direct Modeling Express” and sliced with “Simplify3D”. Programming was done with “Bascom”.

Mechanical parts

Nylonthread: 0,25mm, 50cm

Crimping beads: 2 pieces

“Teeli Click” Tea holder: 1 piece: http://www.teeli.com/de/filterhalter/teeli-click.html

Lead balls: ~2mm, Max. 50g

Round steel stainless: 3mm, 194mm

Sewing thread: ~10cm

Spring: 4,7x0,25x8: http://www.bengs-modellbau.de

Metrical screws: 2 pieces, M3x40, Hex socket

Countersunk tapping screws: 4 pieces, 2,2mmx6,5mm

Foam rubber: 3mm, ~5cmx5cm: Use the Cut_Template

(Optionally some device feet)

Electronical parts

USB ISP-Programmer: (such as: https://www.diamex.de/dxshop/DIAMEX-USB-ISP-Programmer-Stick-fuer-AVR)

application board: P012.45-ATMega328P-AU-X (http://shop.anvilex.de/index.php?route=product/product&path=115_222&product_id=2641)

Led1 – 8: 3mm, with integrated resistor!!! (https://www.reichelt.de/LEDs-with-resistor/LED-3MM-5V-GE/3/index.html?ACTION=3&LA=517&ARTICLE=54102&GROUPID=3024&trstct=lsbght_sldr::54093)

R9: ~180 Ohm

tactile switch: length of the actuator ~6mm (Such as: https://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/tactile-switches/4791435/)

photomos relay: AQY212EH (https://www.voelkner.de/products/37800/Photomos-Relais-1A-400ma-60v-Aqy.html)

Ultra Micro Linear Servo: GS-1502 (right version, not left!)

buzzer: ACS95, 9mmx5,4mm!!! (https://www.voelkner.de/products/902241/Miniatur-Summer-85-dB-5-V-ACS95-9-mm-x-5.4-mm-Inhalt-1-St..html)

pinheader: 2x5 pins, 90° (https://www.voelkner.de/products/187996/Stiftleiste-2x5-polig-Gewinkelt-Rm-2-54.html)

cylindrical battery holder 3xAAA: (https://www.ebay.com/itm/3x-AAA-Battery-Plastic-Holder-Box-Case-Cylindrical-Type-For-18650-Flashlight-MA-/131623418470)

battery cable: 2pin Dupont connector, RM 2,54mm, ~30cm length

battery contacts: Plate Size 20 x 12mm (https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00PZT080S/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

Programmer

You need an USB-ISP-programmer with a 10pin-connector or an adaptor. You can find the free version of Bascom here: https://www.mcselec.com/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=139

title: Big AA Battery (remix...Kinda?) [[email protected]]
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A few weeks after getting the yellow AA battery box done, my nephew got a power wheel car with no battery, so i figured i could come up with a battery based on my box.

i picked up two orders of these >>>> https://www.ebay.com/itm/80X-High-energy-1-2V-AA-Rechargeable-Ni-MH-Battery-Green-for-Lifhts-or-Toys/401434155033

80 1.2V batteries @ 3.3AH each,

and these >>> https://www.ebay.com/itm/Wholesale-Silver-Tone-Metal-Spring-Battery-Contact-Plate-Set-For-AAAAA-Batteries/382246713722

each tray takes 16 batteries, and 16 pairs of spring plates. so i printed 5 trays, 4 inter-battery pack spacers and one cover, wired all the batteries in each tray in parallel making each tray worth 2.4V @ 26.4Ah then i wired the 5 trays in series giving me a 12V @ 26.4Ah battery pack, needless to say the 6V little car, now really moves... lol. we had to take an old bike innertube and cut it open and pin nail the rubber to the plastic tires so it would get traction.

Assembly:

Ill give you an idea how to assemble it but you can figure out how you want it wired.

Print :
1 Back Cover
1 Front Cover
3 wire layers
5 Battery Boxes.
roughly 700g

1.I started by putting all the spring plates in the little slots its a very loose fit on these but at the time i was waiting on hong kong post so i could get measurements

  1. once the plates are in install the batteries to hold the plates in place

  2. then using 2 3MM screws install the wire layer over the tray,
    4.turn over and make solder connections. Yes i know these are batteries, and if you didnt know that well we are working with batteries yall, so you have exactly 2 seconds to make your solder connection or you die in a massive fire...just playing, batteries normally get spot welded, im not saying stuff doesnt happen but if you use your grey squish you should be ok. after all your connections are made remove the wire layer cover that you places on to hold the batteries in with,
    5.repeat steps 1 to 4 four more times

  3. this next part is tricky for the hardware impaired . the 6 tabs on the sides of the trays are for all tread rod, or threaded rod or whatever you wanna call it, i use it in nearly all my designs becasue i have about 100lbs of the stuff, it basically makes giant bolts. get 6 pieces of all thread that are the height of your battery stack.
  4. thread one nut on to the very end of each rod
  5. place one washer on to every rod
  6. thread all 6 rods into the holes on the back cover and lay the flat side of the cover, with the nuts and washers facing down,
    10 the back cover has indented recesses so your leads can come through, thread all 6 rods into the first tray and slide it doen the rods, pulling your wires through and into the recesses, keep in mind if you still have the batteries in, the wires are live. (and somewhere around 10Ah to 30Ah amps of power are present depending on your battery selection)
  7. on top of that tray place a wire divide/recess, this performs 2 functions it lets the wires from the tray above it escape, and it hold the batteries in place on the tray below it
    12 repeat steps 10 and 11 until al you have left is the lid...
  8. run the rods through the lid
  9. install washers on all rods
    15 install nuts to all rods, and snug into place,
    16, with a grinder or dremel, depending on your skill level take off the excess rod
    17 torque top nuts to 75in/lb,in a 6 way star pattern this will pull any and all slack that may occur from printing errors and makes the battery pack very solid,
    18, all your leads that come from holes use heat shrink and solder and connect accordingly...
  10. terminate battery leads
  11. plug in and go...

a little more story time.... so then my nephew is on this car and we put it on face book and a friend of a friends dad get ahold of me and asks just how big i can make them, my literal response was, how much do you want to spend... so he commissions me to make a 400Ah battery pack... 1200 AA cells. massive. i changed the design though so that design is for another thing :)

-T

It's also printable with larger nozzles

Charge bock for the 3 x XT battery connections. This eliminates 3-5 charge cables from your charger easily allowing you to connect an XT30, XT60, XT90, JST or JST-SH Servo Plug. A 4.5mm hole was drilled thru the XT90 terminals for the connecting cable (See picture). you will need to take a bit of time and care with the soldering.
"NEVER connect more than one battery to the charge block at the same time."

As most board gamers, I like keeping my components protected and sleeved. Sadly the original box for the card game 'Wizard' wasn't large enough to fit all the components after all the cards were sleeved.
This is a simple box design with a sliding cover, made to hold the components of the game once they are sleeved.
I've included both a cover with the games' logo, and one without it, for people that might want to use this container for other games, or entirely other purposes.
This can also be printed at a greater or smaller scale, but keep in mind the overhand of the lip on the top of the box. The larger you go, the less likely the printer will be able to print on thin air without supports within the model.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Note that the parts should be re-oriented to lay flat on your print bed.
I've also printed this in PLA, at 200c nozzle temperature and 70c bed temperature. It isn't necessary to have a heated bed, but always helps.

Clean-up

Once you have the body and cover printed, there will need to be some clean-up done on the edges of the cover as well as the grooves on the box the cover slides in. The back of an exacto knifes' edge, a file or some fine sandpaper should do the job.
This is to ensure any material that was printed and might have deformed, isn't getting in the way of the cover when you try to slide it in.

description.text:
This mount suits the CM275t all in one FPV camera and transmitter on copters with a 16mm electronics stack at 45°. The camera lens is centred on the craft so weight is shifted slightly off centre. The camera has 10 degrees of tilt which I find is fine for a small 1S build flown indoors.

The copter seen in the photos is a PepperF1SH inspired build using the TinyFISH FC and a ESC/Frame combo of my own design details of which can be found on my blog.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Wall thicknesses are designed for a 0.5mm extrusion width.

After printing drill the mounting holes to 1.5mm and then tap with an M2 thread.
A small dab of hot glue in the bottom of the mount will keep the camera locked in place.

title: Empty Spool Dreidel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you're like me, you probably have a few (if not more) empty filament spools lying around.

This "thing" transforms those empty spools into dreidels.

See it in action here.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

22%

Notes:

This thing is designed for my empty spools all have a 2 inch opening. If your spools differ, your slicer should allow you to re-scale for your opening

Assembly Instructions

  1. Print one bottom, one threaded rod and one top

  2. Twist the rod into the bottom as far as it will go

    • Do not over tighten
    • I find that I can tighten these by hand, but the hole at the end of the rod should fit a 1/4" or 6 mm Allen key

  3. Pass the other end of the threaded rod through the opening in your spool holder

  4. Twist the top onto the rod until the whole assembly turns as a single unit

    • Be sure to align the flat sides of the top with the flat sides of the bottom
  5. Twirl

I have a little dreidel.
I made it out of PLA.
When my printer's finished,
Oh dreidel I shall play.
